title: Tourists tricked as one per cent of tulip bulbs in Amsterdam's famous market will bloom, study reveals
text:
A major investigation into the ‘floating flower market’ tourist attraction in Amsterdam has found that only one per cent of the bulbs on sale actually flowered – and not a single one matched the picture on the packet.

Concerned by signs of growing problems at the once authentic flower market on the Singel canal, Amsterdam council commissioned a study with flower growing town Lisse and the KAVB Dutch bulb growers’ association.

The study involved buying 102 packets of bulbs from 15 sellers in the market late in April and then planting the 1364 bulbs. The specialist grower BQ Support found that despite its greatest efforts, only 14 plants (one per cent) produced flowers. The vast majority – 92 per cent – failed to produce any kind of plant at all.

A similar investigation was done into sellers on the famous “flower boulevard” in the major flower town of Lisse, and found that only two per cent of bulbs flowered and only one plant matched the photo. Amsterdam city and the KAVB have reported the flower sellers to the Dutch consumer authority ACM for ‘misleading sales’.

René le Clercq, chairman of the KAVB, called for urgent action to eradicate what he described as a long-practised scam. “Millions of tourists and day trippers are victims each year,” he said in a statement. “But the tulip is our national symbol, bulb trade is important for the Dutch economy and we are horrified that organised scammers are misleading consumers and damaging the sector’s image.”
